description: Maintainer configuration for workload classification and auto-exclusion. This file controls two independent systems.

_maintainerGuide.overview: This file has three sections that the maintainer controls. Classification and auto-exclusion are INDEPENDENT — a VM can be classified AND excluded.

authoritativeClassifications.purpose: Maintainer-defined CLASSIFICATION — pins specific VMs to a workload type. AI CANNOT override these. Only a user can override via the UI.
authoritativeClassifications.priority: Highest classification priority after user overrides. Precedence: User > Maintainer > AI > Pattern Match.
authoritativeClassifications.howToAdd: Add an entry with match type (contains, startsWith, endsWith, exact, regex), patterns array, and a 'category' key referencing a workload type defined in 'categories'.

categories.purpose: Defines workload types (e.g., Databases, Middleware) and FALLBACK pattern matching. Patterns here are used when AI is not available and no maintainer authoritative rule matched.
categories.priority: Lowest classification priority — only used as fallback when AI is unavailable.
categories.howToAdd: Add a new key under 'categories' with name, icon, description, and patterns array. Patterns are matched case-insensitively against VM names and annotations.

autoExclusionRules.purpose: Migration SCOPE — determines which VMs are auto-excluded from migration (e.g., templates, powered-off, VMware infrastructure).
autoExclusionRules.priority: Auto-exclusion ALWAYS applies regardless of AI or classification. Independent from workload type assignment.
autoExclusionRules.userOverride: Users can force-include auto-excluded VMs or manually exclude included VMs via the UI.
autoExclusionRules.howToAdd: Add fieldRules for VM property checks (template, powerState) or namePatterns for VM name matching (contains, startsWith, endsWith, exact, regex).

_maintainerGuide.example: A 'cust-edge' VM has an authoritativeClassification pinning it to 'network' (Network Equipment). It also has an autoExclusionRule excluding it from migration. AI cannot reclassify it, but a user can override both the workload type and the exclusion.

authoritativeClassifications.description: Maintainer-defined classifications that AI CANNOT override. Only user overrides take priority. Use this to pin specific VMs to a workload type by name pattern.

rules.description: Network edge appliances — always classify as Network Equipment regardless of AI

middleware.name: Middleware / Application Servers
middleware.description: Application servers and web infrastructure often require reconfiguration for cloud deployment. Consider containerizing stateless middleware where possible, and verify vendor support for the target platform.

databases.name: Databases
databases.description: Database VMs require careful migration planning due to data integrity, replication, and performance requirements. Consider managed database services where appropriate, and plan for data migration windows.

enterprise.name: Enterprise Applications
enterprise.description: Enterprise applications (SAP, SharePoint, etc.) often have complex dependencies, licensing constraints, and vendor-specific migration requirements. Engage application owners early in the planning process.

backup.name: Backup & Recovery
backup.description: Backup and recovery infrastructure may need to be replaced with cloud-native solutions. Evaluate IBM Cloud backup services and ensure data protection continuity during migration.

security.name: Security & Compliance
security.description: Security appliances and compliance tools may require platform-specific alternatives in IBM Cloud. Review VPC Security Groups, Network ACLs, and IBM Cloud security services as potential replacements.

monitoring.name: Monitoring & Management
monitoring.description: Monitoring and management tools may need reconfiguration or replacement with cloud-native observability solutions. Consider IBM Cloud Monitoring, Log Analysis, and Activity Tracker.

virtualization.name: Virtualization Infrastructure
virtualization.description: VMware virtualization infrastructure (vCenter, NSX, vSAN) is typically not migrated. These components are replaced by the target platform's native infrastructure.

containers.name: Container Platforms
containers.description: Existing container platforms may be consolidated into the target ROKS environment. Evaluate container workload portability and orchestration compatibility.

messaging.name: Messaging & Integration
messaging.description: Messaging and integration middleware requires careful handling of message queues and data in-flight during migration. Consider IBM Cloud Event Streams (Kafka) and MQ services.

storage.name: Storage Systems
storage.description: Virtual storage appliances may need to be replaced with IBM Cloud Block Storage, File Storage, or Object Storage services depending on access patterns and performance requirements.

network.name: Network Equipment
network.description: Virtual network appliances (routers, load balancers, firewalls) often require platform-specific alternatives. Consider IBM Cloud VPC native services like Load Balancer for VPC, Security Groups, and Network ACLs as potential replacements.

cloud.name: Cloud Services
cloud.description: Existing cloud service integrations and infrastructure-as-code tools may need reconfiguration for the IBM Cloud target environment. Review Terraform providers and automation scripts.

devops.name: DevOps & CI/CD
devops.description: CI/CD pipelines and DevOps tools typically continue operating after migration with updated deployment targets. Plan for pipeline reconfiguration to target IBM Cloud environments.

identity.name: Identity & Access
identity.description: Identity and access management services are critical infrastructure. Plan for integration with IBM Cloud IAM and ensure directory services connectivity is maintained during migration.

autoExclusionRules.description: Migration SCOPE rules — auto-exclude VMs from migration. Independent from classification (categories above). Always applies regardless of AI. Users can override via UI. A VM can match multiple rules.

fieldRules.label: Template
fieldRules.description: VM is a template, not a running workload

namePatterns.label: VMware Infrastructure
namePatterns.description: NSX edge naming conventions (edge-01, t0-edge, etc.) excluding network appliances

namePatterns.label: Network Edge Appliance
namePatterns.description: Network edge appliances (e.g., Cisco routers) — not VMware infrastructure
